Users Workshop

The workshop will cover the following topics: GeoNode from a user perspective, how to. It will cover tipical functionalities and use cases a GeoNode user, either Administrator and Standard, will face. Accounts, users and groups. Resource types handled by GeoNode, how to upload, set permissions, edit metadata and tweak to improve your portal usability. Management of geospatial datasets, diffrent types and how to nicely apply styling to them. Creation of Maps, and share them with the world. Accessing GeoNode from other Desktop and Web GIS applications. As an Administrator, manage the GeoNode data, throubleshoot and fix the most common issues.

View presentation

One Geonode, many Geonodes

GeoSolutions has been involved into a number of projects, ranging from local administrations to global institutions, involving GeoNode deployments, customizations and enhancements. A gallery of projects and use cases will showcase the versatility and effectiveness of GeoNode, both as a standalone application and as a service component, for building secured geodata catalogs and web mapping services. Lastly, ongoing and future developments will be presented ranging from the upcoming integration with MapStore to the monitoring and analytics dashboard or the support for time series data.

View presentation

Code Sprint

A sprint is getting contributors together and work on Open Source software, testing, documentation and providing feedback. There are roles needed to be filled, no matter what your expertise, so everyone is welcome. This code sprint goal is working on the GeoNode version 2.8.

Roadmap Discussion

Join the GeoNode developers community to discuss about the future of GeoNode. Users and developers will discuss together how and when the current major version (2.x) of GeoNode will evolve and what the next versions (3.x +) will be.

Alessio Fabiani , Geosolutions

Eng. Alessio Fabiani is a Software Engineer, co-founder of GeoSolutions S.A.S., with more than 10 years experience in C++, Java and Python development, currently working as Software Engineer, Technical Lead and Team Leader at GeoSolutions. Involved in many worldwide relevant GIS OpenSource projects, core developer and member of the projects management/steering committees, like GeoServer, GeoTools and GeoNode.

GeoNode 0.1 to 3.0

A recount of GeoNode's history from the first version to the current plans and my personal vision for GeoNode 3.0 and its API.

View presentation

Roadmap Discussion

Join the GeoNode developers community to discuss about the future of GeoNode. Users and developers will discuss together how and when the current major version (2.x) of GeoNode will evolve and what the next versions (3.x +) will be.

Ariel Nu√±ez , Terranodo

Specialist in open-source software. Co-creator of GeoNode and active contributor as core developer.

Challenges and successes in sharing geospatial data in Africa

View presentation

Bernard Justus Muhwezi , Uganda Bureau of Statistics (UBOS)

Bernard Justus Muhwezi is the Head, Geo-Information Services Division at Uganda Bureau of Statistics (UBOS) with responsibility for Geospatial Data Coordination and Geo-Information Management for Statistical Production and Dissemination for 18 years. Prior to joining UBOS, Bernard Justus worked in Ministry of Lands, Housing and Economic Development, Department of Surveys and Mapping as a Senior Staff Cartographer at several projects level including: Computer Assisted Mapping Uganda Survey Project for district-based geo-information for local government public service delivery, administration and management; and Greater Kampala Metropolitan Mapping Project for comprehensive sustainable planning of Kampala Capital City Authority. Notable is his 6 years as Assistant Lecturer (Physics, Mathematics and Surveying) at Uganda Polytechnic Kyambogo.

GeoNode Roundtable and closing remarks

Open discussion on lessons learned. Wrapping up and logistics information about the social events and Day 3.

Cristiano Giovando , World Bank Group

Cristiano Giovando is a geographer and advocate of open data and open source geospatial software. At the World Bank he works on OpenDRI, promoting the use of community mapping methods for local preparedness and disaster risk management. He previously held scientific and technical roles at the EC Joint Research Centre and the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team.

Adding Raster Analysis Tools to the GeoNode Experience

Computers, including mobile devices, continue to become more powerful, opening up pathways for GIS that haven't existed before. GeoTIFF.io, is an open-source community-driven project, and a website that allows users to analyze rasters completely in their browser. This presentation will go over a proposed simple addition of a button to GeoNode pages that would allow a user to open up the raster layers in GeoTIFF.io. GeoTIFF.io, as it processes everything client-side and is hosted on Github Pages, is completely free and can scale nearly infinitely. Specifically, GeoTIFF.io has been used to analyze pasturelands in Europe, access to ante-natal care in Rwanda, rainfed wheat in Ukraine and much more.

Daniel Dufour , GeoTIFF.io

Daniel J. Dufour is the founder of GeoTIFF.io, FirstDraftGIS.com, and TweetGeoLocator.com. He also works as the lead front-end developer of code.gov. Previously, he lead development of the Global Agricultural and Disaster Assessment System at the U.S. Department of Agriculture. He is also a fellow emeritus of MapStory.org, a website based on GeoNode that empowers users to tell stories about change over time using maps.

Building Flood Models with Geonode

I've paired Geonode with the open-source 2d hydrodynamic flood model, ANUGA, to create a collaborative online flood modelling environment. This allows us to move both flood model inputs and outputs into an adaptable, transparent online hydraulic model that gets better with time, as opposed to that PDF version going out-of-date on your hard drive. The mission is to reduce the hassle involved in building and maintaining up-to-date flood models, especially in the years after the original consultancy contract is complete. I'll present a brief demonstration of the application, followed by a technical architecture overview and some lessons learned along the way.

View presentation

David Kennewell , Hydrata

I'm a chartered Environmental Engineer and geospatial web developer. I help manage human impacts on our water resources. This often means working with infrastructure projects or cities to transparently manage their data, their modelling and the presentation of environmental impact assessments. The first 10 years of my career was with large engineering consultancies, however now I work through a small independent company.

WFP GeoNode Use cases and Roadmap

In this presentation we will describe a set of functionalities and customizations we have implemented in WFP GeoNode (based on GeoNode 2.4) such as a query builder functionality and a map tool for filtering and downloading vector layers, a create new layer functionality with arbitrary number of columns, a create new layer functionality based on administrative boundaries, an editing data app alternative to the existing one and a customization to the remote services app, which allows selecting the layers to be created. Additionally we will present the current position of WFP GeoNode in our GIS infrastructure, the role of the platform as a data hub and a number of use cases and projects in which GeoNode and other tools join forces to accomplish tasks.

View presentation

Dimitris Karakostis , World Food Programme

Dimitris Karakostis is a geoinformatics specialist and a web gis developer with a Ms in Geoinformatics (TU Berlin) and a Diploma in Mining Engineering (TU Crete). Dimitris has four plus years of working experience in GIS related projects, development of web GIS information systems, designing and management of (spatial) databases and implementation of complex workflows.

ADB SPADE: exploring and analysing infrastructure and climate data

Finding the balance between out-of-the-box GeoNode implementation, a user interface as simple as possible & advanced analysis tools to support climate change resilient infrastructure project planning, implementation and monitoring.

View presentation

Erwin Sterrenburg , Royal HaskoningDHV

I am a civil engineer with a healthy interest in GIS and mapping, working as a consultant Geo-ICT for Royal HaskoningDHV, an international, engineering consultancy firm with headquarters in the Netherlands and operating worldwide.

Geonode roadmap in Madagascar

In 2017, Madagascar was ranked 178 out of 180 among the countries which have already opened its data. However, we have implemented Geonode platform. So I will present the activities done since the deployment and the challenge for maintain as well as animate. Then, featured we added on our instance.

View presentation

Fanevanjanahary Andriamiadantsoa , Cellule de Pr√©vention et Gestion des Urgences (CPGU)

Graduated from IT (Mobiquity Databases and System Integration) on November 2017, Faneva worked on the Geonode instance in Madagascar during her internship in 2015. She continued to help local organizations to use and maintain this platform. She works with a NGO in Madagascar to implement an open data platform used a OpenStreetMap and Big data technic there.

Developers Workshop

The workshop will cover the following topics: GeoNode in development mode, how to. The geonode-project to customize GeoNode. Change the look and feel. Add your own app. Add your own models, views and logic. Build your own APIs. Add a third party app. Deploy your customized GeoNode.

View presentation

GeoNode DevOps with Docker and Rancher

GeoNode is an easy to use platform for developing web based Geospatial Information Systems and for deploying interoperable and OGC standards compliant Spatial Data Infrastructure (SDI). The platform can be composed and extended with different components like Elasticsearch, GeoGig, QGIS Server beyond the common ones GeoServer, PostGIS and pycsw as an example. This model of a such SDI is natively fitting very well with the cloud approach of Software As a Service (SaaS) and looks at the new DevOps technologies like Ansible and Docker for optimizing the scale up and make an easier deployment for the end users. Docker and its orchestration tool docker-compose has been extensively used to strengthen the configuration and the start of each single component. The talk aims to describe how GeoNode images have been designed and docker volumes are used for data configuration, finally how docker-compose can be used by Rancher stacks. The presentation will provide an introduction to the state of the art and examples on how to deploy GeoNode with Docker for development or to use Rancher for production environments into AWS.

View presentation

Francesco Bartoli , Geobeyond

Telecommunication Engineer, security and spatial IT geek with opinionated mind to open source software. Hugely passionate lover of mountain activities and landscape. Francesco is the founder and Chief Technical Officer at Geobeyond. He started GeoAvalanche in 2013, a spatial data infrastructure for snow avalanche information which is based on GeoNode and now he is an actively contributor.

WFP GeoNode Use cases and Roadmap

In this presentation we will describe a set of functionalities and customizations we have implemented in WFP GeoNode (based on GeoNode 2.4) such as a query builder functionality and a map tool for filtering and downloading vector layers, a create new layer functionality with arbitrary number of columns, a create new layer functionality based on administrative boundaries, an editing data app alternative to the existing one and a customization to the remote services app, which allows selecting the layers to be created. Additionally we will present the current position of WFP GeoNode in our GIS infrastructure, the role of the platform as a data hub and a number of use cases and projects in which GeoNode and other tools join forces to accomplish tasks.

View presentation

Governance Roundtable

GeoNode is now a mature and successful open source project, but surprisingly still lacking a formal governance framework. Let's discuss what model could be adopted for making it easier for organizations to join and contribute to GeoNode's development.

Francesco Stompanato , World Food Programme

Telecommunication engineer with a strong passion for geography and Open Source technologies for Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Management. Since mid-2011 I‚Äôm supporting the Emergency Preparedness & Response division in WFP in the implementation and management of systems and initiatives for efficient management and sharing of geospatial information. GeoNode addicted.

GeoNode with QGIS, GeoNode for DRR

Over the last year we have done a number of GeoNode related developments, which relate to integration of GeoNode with QGIS and with using GeoNode for Disaster Risk Reduction. We have also been working to make GeoNode (with QGIS Backend) easily deployable using Rancher and Docker - which we will demonstrate. This presentation will be like a Christmas hamper where we quickly show you the highlights of our work!

View presentation

Gavin Fleming , Kartoza

Gavin is a Professional GISc Practitioner (PGP 1234), a Charter Member of the Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo), on the advisory board of the CGIS at the University of Pretoria, on the National Council of GISSA and has an MSc. He started in the GIS industry in 1996 and his experience includes thirteen years with the full suite of ESRI software and since 2005 with a wide range of FOSS GIS tools. He worked at GIMS (now ESRI), CSIR, Mintek and SAEON before starting AfriSpatial in 2010 and Kartoza in 2014 with Tim Sutton. He is passionate about Open Source Software, Open Data and other Open philosophies that lead to interoperability, empower people and help maximise returns on spending. He is also convinced that Free and Open Source GIS software is mature and ready to integrate with or replace existing expensive alternatives, in line with the Government Open Source policy. After bringing FOSS4G 2008 to South Africa and working almost exclusively with FOSS since then he has picked up a surge in demand and usage of FOSS GIS in all sectors in South Africa and globally and coupled with that, a growing base of service providers and related resources.

Users Workshop

The workshop will cover the following topics: GeoNode from a user perspective, how to. It will cover tipical functionalities and use cases a GeoNode user, either Administrator and Standard, will face. Accounts, users and groups. Resource types handled by GeoNode, how to upload, set permissions, edit metadata and tweak to improve your portal usability. Management of geospatial datasets, diffrent types and how to nicely apply styling to them. Creation of Maps, and share them with the world. Accessing GeoNode from other Desktop and Web GIS applications. As an Administrator, manage the GeoNode data, throubleshoot and fix the most common issues.

View presentation

Challenge Fund Data Exploration

A data exploration tool for risk related data is under development by GeoSolutions for the World Bank's Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery global partnership. As part of the Challenge Fund program, this tool aims at providing a centralized, global, database for exposures, hazards and vulnerabilities data sets. The data exploration tool is being developed leveraging on MapStore and GeoNode to provide stakeholders with a user-friendly access to the rich database of information and data useful for risk analysis and disaster management. Such platform will also try to lay out the foundations for GeoNode 3, the new version of the popular Open Source platform.

View presentation

Giovanni Allegri , Geosolutions

Giovanni Allegri is a GIS and EO specialist, with a scientific background in Earth Science. He has more then 10 years experience in spatial data mangement, data management platforms and spatial data analysis. He has worked as a freelance consultant, software developer (in particular QGIS, Python and WebGIS products) and technical lead in numerous projects for public institutions, the talian Research Council and private companies.

GeoDASH Customize for Bangladesh and Base for NSDI. Bangladesh National Enterprise Architecture (BNEA) and GeoDASH Platform

The Bangladesh Geospatial Data Sharing Platform (GeoDASH) is a web-based spatial data infrastructure and GIS that empowers government, academia, private enterprise and the public to securely host, manage, share, visualize and analyze geospatial data. GeoDASH overview, Unique features, BNEA overview, Open Group Award 2018, relation between GeoDASH and BNEA, future activities of GeoDASH and BNEA.

View presentation

Hamid Mohammed Abu , World Bank Group

Mohammed Abu Hamid is a GeoDASH System Consultant at the the World Bank, Bangladesh. GeoDASH is a GFDRR funded GIS data sharing platform for Bangladesh based on GeoNode which is now under the ownership of Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC), a statuary body of Government of Bangladesh. The World Bank continues its support to upgrade GeoDASH and Mr. Hamid is managing the development process. He has vast experience in project management and successfully lead many national level projects since 2009 in the fields of Disaster Management, Water and Sanitation, Financial and ICT capacity building of government organizations. Prior to that he worked as software developer in national and international organisations since 2002. He is graduated in Electronics and Communication Engineering. Currently Bangladesh government developing prototype National Spatial Data Infrastructure (NSDI) based on GeoDASH with the support from JICA. Mr. Hamid providing the technical guidance to the respective agencies for the successful completion of this initiative.

Geonode integration with town planning management software

This talk is about the demonstrating the use of geonode as map composer and GIS proxy in order to show simple maps in open-source town planning management software in Belgium. Tailoring maps inside geonode help towns to get the needed legal and informative layers online and/or get directly connected to the regional GIS service portal in order to make decision on up-to-date data and share maps inside the town administration.

Nicolas Dufrane , Geode SPRL

GIS Developer and Open-source enthusiast.

Customizing GeoNode

ITHACA has been working on GeoNode since 2011. From the first European Commission to the latest World Bank funded projects this presentation is a showcase of GeoNode installations made by ITHACA with their own customizations. It's also a brief (not exhaustive) journey into the evolution of GeoNode, from the initial concept by OpenGeo and GFDRR to the current version highlighting some goods and bads.

View presentation

Paolo Pasquali , ITHACA

Paolo is a web GIS Specialist at ITHACA (Information Technology for Humanitarian Assistance, Cooperation and Action) based in Torino. Has 15+ years of experience in designing and developing geospatial applications. Has been installing GeoNode platforms around the world since 2011.

Welcome Address

Piero Boccardo, Director of ITHACA, will give a warm welcome and address the GeoNode Summit.

Piero Boccardo , ITHACA

Director of ITHACA and Professor in Remote Sensing at Politecnico di Torino since 2001, supervisor of more than 70 degree and PhD theses, author of more than 100 scientific publications. Managed several projects in the field of Remote Sensing, GIS and Information Technology especially in support of Disaster Management. President of the AIT (Remote Sensing Italian Association) since 2010; President of the public company 5T; Member of the Steering Committee of ASITA (Federation of Scientific Associations for Environmental Information).

Malawi Spatial Data Portal (MASDAP)

Malawi become the first user of Geonode in Africa in the year 2012. MASDAP is a government portal used so storing GIS data. This talk will cover the following topics: Location of Malawi; MASDAP Background; MASDAP Development; Economies of open data; MASDAP site administration; Geospatial data in MASDAP; Layers in MASDAP; Categories of dataset; Main functionalities; Functions within MASDAP; Way forward.

Silence Chirwa , Malawi Department of Surveys

Developers Workshop

The workshop will cover the following topics: GeoNode in development mode, how to. The geonode-project to customize GeoNode. Change the look and feel. Add your own app. Add your own models, views and logic. Build your own APIs. Add a third party app. Deploy your customized GeoNode.

View presentation

Simone Dalmasso , European Commission - DG Joint Research Centre

Environmental Engineer and Ph.D. in Geomatics with passion for Geospatial Open Source Software, Simone is working at the European Commission DG-JRC based on the lake Maggiore in north Italy where he is in charge for the Copernicus EMS Rapid Mapping technical management and supervision. Simone is a GeoNode core developer since 2011 and OSGeo Charter member.

User-centered design session 1

The first of two design session where we will work together as a community to explore how the current GeoNode experience can be improved for developers as well as for users. Session one will focus on uncovering the problems and obstacles encountered when using and working with GeoNode. We will using a series or fast paced and highly collaborative exercises to identify, arrange and rank issues in preparation for session 2 in the afternoon. To get ready, start thinking of points where changes to GeoNode would make your work easier.

User-centered design session 2

This is the second of two design sessions. It will build on the work from the morning session to explore potential solutions the obstacles facing GeoNode users and developers. Once again, it will be hands-on, fast-paced and collaborative. You don't need to have attended the morning design session to contribute to this one, though it will help.

Steph Bannister , Human-Centred Design Consultant

I‚Äôve been a designer for more than 15 years. I started in visual communication but have spent most of that time creating digital products and services, along with the concepts and strategies that support them. I‚Äôve done this for large organisations, non-profits, and start-ups in many different sectors: humanitarian, health, employment, government, retail and advertising. I‚Äôve worked on and led teams of all sizes and shapes, alongside everyone from members of the public to members of the board. I know how it important an inquisitive, collaborative approach to design is. And I believe that the same skills and methods that go into making a good, fit-for-market product can be applied to solving the complex, socially-focussed problems facing us today.

The Maplovers Guide to the Galaxy - is GeoNode the answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything?

“Metadata is dull. Really dull. You just won‚Äôt believe how vastly, hugely, mindbogglingly dull it is. I mean, you may think reviewing other people's code is dull, but that‚Äôs just peanuts to metadata.” - how to make metadata catalogues engaging

“He was staring at the search interface with the air of one who is trying to convert Fahrenheit to centigrade in his head while his house is burning down.” - how to find what you really need

“It seemed to me, said Wonko the Sane, that any civilization that had so far lost its head as to need to include a set of detailed instructions for use in a spatial data catalogue, was no longer a civilization in which I could live and stay sane.” - how to make it intuitive, and to give the right instructions where needed

“Forty-two”, said GeoNode, with infinite majesty and calm. - many GeoNode instances have 42 or less layers/maps/documents in them, how do we avoid this, and in any case, what is the question?

“Don't panic.” - GeoNode already does a great job, but how can it be made even better?

View presentation

Stephen Peedell , European Commission - DG Joint Research Centre

Steve Peedell leads the Biodiversity and Protected Areas Management (BIOPAMA) programme at the European Commission Joint Research Centre, mapping areas of high nature value across African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. He has been working with geospatial information technology for the last 30 years and was involved in many projects to improve collaborative use of data and systems for environmental management, including the early work on the Infrastructure for Spatial Information in Europe (INSPIRE)

The Bangladesh Geospatial Data Sharing Platform (GeoDASH) is a web-based spatial data infrastructure and GIS that empowers government, academia, private enterprise and the public to securely host, manage, share, visualize and analyze geospatial data. GeoDASH overview, Unique features, BNEA overview, Open Group Award 2018, relation between GeoDASH and BNEA, future activities of GeoDASH and BNEA.

View presentation

Tanimul Bari , Bangladesh Computer Council

Mr. Tanimul Bari is a Technical Specialist in the e-Government Component of the World Bank funded project ‚ÄúLeveraging ICT for Growth, Employment and Governance‚Äù under Bangladesh Computer Council (BCC). He is the team leader of National Enterprise Architecture (NEA) and e-Government Interoperability Framework (e-GIF) development team for the Government of Bangladesh. He advises the government organizations on designing and architecting Information Systems so that they are aligned to their business needs and seamless flow of information between different information systems is ensured. Mr. Bari has experience of designing wide variety of high-exposure, complex, mission-critical Systems and services for many public and private sector organizations in Bangladesh. Mr. Bari is a Top Rated Information Technology (IT) professional and received the highest peer recognition for ethical standards, managerial and technical ability. He has achieved a Bachelor Degree in Computer Science from the Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology (BUET) in 2003. Mr. Bari is also a Certified ISO 27001 Lead Auditor and a Certified COBIT foundation professional. He has visited several countries and participated in several national/international conferences, workshops and seminars.

Governance Roundtable

GeoNode is now a mature and successful open source project, but surprisingly still lacking a formal governance framework. Let's discuss what model could be adopted for making it easier for organizations to join and contribute to GeoNode's development.

Vivien Deparday , World Bank Group

Vivien Deparday is a Disaster Risk Management Specialist at the Global Facility for Disaster Risk Reduction (GFDRR) at the World Bank. He leads GFDRR‚Äôs Open Data for Resilience Initiative (OpenDRI). He is a member of the GFDRR Innovation Lab, supporting World Bank teams across the globe by providing technical and strategic assistance to help governments better collect, share, and use information, as well as develop tools and build long-term capacity to support decisions to reduce the impact of disasters. Vivien has extensive experience in geospatial technology, community mapping, open source, open data and more generally in bringing open innovation to resilience projects.

GeoNode - an additional set of functionalities

During this presentation we will review a set of functionalities which we are adding to GeoNode to support use cases such as a resumable upload allowing the batch upload of large resources including File GeoDatabases and imagery tiles, the ability to upload tabular data (e.g. csv, spss, stata, etc.) and turn it into a point layer if it contains latitude and longitude information, the ability to connect to layers hosted on GeoNode from desktop clients such as QGIS or ArcMap, the ability to search place names and navigate geo-spatially to these location on the map, the ability to draw polygons to query any raster to estimate population in given areas for instance, the ability to reference layers between GeoNode instances, the dockerization of the platform and support for S3 for a scalable and affordable production environment, etc.

Yoann Mira , Novel-T

An engineer with 8 years of experience, Yoann joined Novel-T in 2014. His expertise combines in-depth knowledge of GIS (Geographic Information System), both Esri and Open-source with strong Full-Stack web development experience using JavaScript and Python technologies.
